docs.lead_paragraph: Washington State, which will account for only 2.2 percent of delegates at the Democratic National Convention this year, has unexpectedly emerged as a battleground for the two men seeking the party's presidential nomination, and Al Gore spent much of the weekend here trying to make sure that Bill Bradley would have nothing to show for his effort to win the state's primary on Tuesday. Mr. Bradley suspended his national campaign last week to spend time in Washington. He needs a victory here to resuscitate his candidacy. His decision to spend precious campaign time here, rather than in big states like California and New York, which vote on March 7, puzzled many political professionals.

headline.main: Gore Matches Bradley Efforts With Washington State Visit

docs.abstract: Washington State, which will account for only 2.2 percent of delegates at Democratic National Convention, unexpectedly emerges as battleground for Democratic presidential candidates Vice Pres Al Gore and former Sen Bill Bradley (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It is show-me time for Healtheon/ WebMD. The Internet-based company has riveted investors the last year, as its stock price rode a roller coaster while Healtheon announced a dizzying array of mergers and alliances. This month alone, Healtheon has used its stock in $5.7 billion worth of takeover deals for three companies.

headline.main: Confronting the Reality Of a Health Care Vision

docs.abstract: Healtheon/WebMD hopes to transform nation's unruly, fragmented health system into digitally disciplined online universe; vision is to link patients, doctors and insurers online, promoting self-help for patients while saving time and money by eliminating paperwork and insurance company phone centers; Jeffrey T Arnold, chief executive, says company now has assets in place to execute its vision, after dizzying array of mergers and alliances announced in last year; analysts say it may take years for Healtheon to accomplish daunting task it has undertaken; company's major stakeholders include Microsoft, DuPont and Rupert Murdoch's News Corp; photos; chart; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: RARELY have voters had such a clear opportunity to let Washington know what they want to do about taxes. It is a presidential election year, and between the two major parties, the four leading candidates are offering a spectrum of proposals. At one end of the spectrum is Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, who generally wants to provide tax relief of Reaganesque proportions; at the other is former Senator Bill Bradley, who has called for only limited tax cuts to reduce poverty and improve health care. Mr. Bush's Republican rival, Senator John McCain of Arizona, champions a substantial tax-cutting package, although much smaller than Mr. Bush's, and Vice President Al Gore supports modest tax cuts.

headline.main: How the 2000 Ballot Could Amend Form 1040

docs.abstract: While taxes have always played some role in presidential politics, this year they are bigger issue than usual because there is big budget surplus, estimated at as much as $1.9 billion over next decade; four leading candidates are offering spectrum of proposals about what they want to do about taxes; positions of Republican presidential aspirants George W Bush and John McCain and Democrats Bill Bradley and Vice Pres Gore discussed; photos; charts on their tax ideas (Money and Business, Part 2) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: MUCH of the tax agenda that Republicans promised in the ''Contract With America'' has been enacted into law in the last five years. But as Newt Gingrich, the contract's author, is fond of saying: There is no free lunch. The contract's new tax breaks for middle-class parents, investors, the self-employed and others have come at a price that millions of Americans are discovering as they engage in the annual ritual of filing their income tax returns: a complexity that might make even Rube Goldberg indignant.

headline.main: The Tax Maze Begins Here. No, Here. No . . .

docs.abstract: Much of tax aggenda that Republicans promised in Contract With America has been enacted, but contract's tax breaks have come at price that millions of Americans are discovering as they prepare their tax returns: ever greater complexity; Federal tax laws and regulations filled 40,500 pages when Republicans took charge of Congress in 1995, according to CHH Inc, publisher of tax information; in last five years, 6,400 pages have been added; much of complexity is restimony to political horse-trading by which such tax laws get written; article offers look at some ways tax law has grown muddier over last few years; photos; chart shows income levels where various tax phase-outs begfin (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: IMAGINE being the new kid on the block. Then imagine that you are not a kid -- and that no one on the block speaks your language. Most of the thousands of Hispanic immigrants in the county face that situation daily. Inhibited by limited English, uncertain about how to fill out everything from apartment leases and school registration to medical forms and managing a bank account, simply getting through daily chores can be daunting.

headline.main: Helping Hispanic Clients Adjust to a New Life

docs.lead_paragraph: ASK Martin J. Wygod about his mentors and he cites Fletcher Jones, a software pioneer; Fred Carr, the investment manager; and Manny Kalish. Mr. Kalish, his first mentor, was a gambler who handicapped horses for New York tabloids. Mr. Wygod, who spent time at Belmont and other tracks with fellow racing fans from Lawrence High School on Long Island, says Mr. Kalish gave him his first lessons in picking winners.
docs.abstract: Profile of Martin J Wygod, who recently agreed to sell two health care businesses he started, Medical Manager Corp and CareInsite Inc, to Healtheon/WebMD for more than $5 billion; one Wall Street analysts calls Wygod smartest person in health care industry; earlier deals by Wygod culminated in his sale of Medco Containment Services, managed care drug distributor, to Merck & Co in 1993 for $6.6 billion; Wygod photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Melissa Joy Algranati, a heath and fitness consultant, and Kenneth Edward Berger, a sportswriter, are to be married today in Fresh Meadows, Queens. Rabbi Hyman Levine will perform the ceremony at the Fresh Meadows Jewish Center. The bride, 25, works for the Girl Scouts of the U.S.A. in Manhattan. She graduated from the State University at Binghamton, N.Y., and received a master's degree in public health from Columbia University. She is a daughter of Mary Algranati of Whitestone, Queens, and the late Jacques Algranati. The bride's mother is a teacher's aide at Public School 169 in Bayside, Queens. Her father was an account executive for Ferrari Foods, a former distributor in Manhasset, N.Y.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''The Bradley Trip'' (column, Feb. 24), by Bob Herbert: The implicit message in Al Gore's ''step-by-step'' approach to health care reform is that the steps will be in the right direction: the Clinton administration's approach since the failure of its comprehensive health plan.

headline.main: On Health Care, Gore or Bradley?

docs.lead_paragraph: Richard L. Huber, 63, the embattled chief executive of Aetna Inc., the nation's biggest health insurance company, resigned yesterday in response to pressure from shareholders frustrated by a 50 percent decline in the stock since last August. He was replaced by William H. Donaldson, a Wall Street veteran whose first task may be trying to repair frayed relations with unhappy investors. Mr. Donaldson, 68, a former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, said he would step down as a senior adviser at Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette, the Wall Street securities and banking firm that he founded 41 years ago with Daniel Lufkin and Richard Jenrette.

headline.main: Aetna's Chief Steps Down Under Pressure From Shareholders

docs.abstract: Richard L Huber resigns as Aetna Inc chief executive under pressure from shareholders frustrated by stock price slide; is succeeded by William H Donaldson, board member who will step down as senior adviser at Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette; Donaldson, 68, says he will not be interim chief; board waives its mandatory age 65 retirement policy for him; photo (M)
